claim: French people do not have bad breath.

supporting.text: French cuisine emphasizes fresh ingredients like herbs and vegetables, which can contribute to better oral hygiene and fresher breath.

attacks.text: French cuisine emphasizes fresh ingredients like herbs and vegetables, which can contribute to better oral hygiene and fresher breath.
French cuisine also includes strong-smelling foods like garlic and onions, which are known to cause bad breath.
Many French people consume coffee and wine regularly, which can contribute to dry mouth and bad breath.
Oral hygiene practices, such as brushing and flossing, are more significant determinants of breath freshness than diet alone.

supporting.text: Smoking rates in France are relatively high compared to some other countries, and smoking is a known cause of bad breath.

attacks.text: Smoking rates in France are relatively high compared to some other countries, and smoking is a known cause of bad breath.
Not all smokers have chronic bad breath, as oral hygiene can mitigate the effects of smoking.
Studies show that smokers are significantly more likely to suffer from halitosis (bad breath) than non-smokers, regardless of oral hygiene.
Smoking rates in France have been declining in recent years, reducing the impact of this factor.
Despite declining rates, France still has one of the highest smoking rates in Europe, maintaining a significant impact on population-level bad breath.

supporting.text: France has a strong culture of dental care, with regular dental check-ups being common, which helps maintain oral health and prevent bad breath.

attacks.text: France has a strong culture of dental care, with regular dental check-ups being common, which helps maintain oral health and prevent bad breath.
While dental care is common, dietary habits like consuming garlic, onions, and wine can still cause bad breath regardless of dental hygiene.
Not all French people have access to or prioritize dental care, especially in rural or low-income areas.
Modern oral hygiene products like mouthwash and sugar-free gum can mitigate bad breath from dietary habits.
Public healthcare in France includes subsidized dental care, reducing barriers for low-income populations.

supporting.text: The consumption of strong-smelling foods like garlic and cheese, which are staples in French cuisine, can contribute to temporary bad breath.

attacks.text: The consumption of strong-smelling foods like garlic and cheese, which are staples in French cuisine, can contribute to temporary bad breath.
Not all French people consume strong-smelling foods regularly, so this argument does not apply universally.
Oral hygiene practices like brushing and mouthwash can mitigate bad breath from food, regardless of cuisine.
Other cultures also consume strong-smelling foods, so this is not unique to French people.
Studies show that bad breath is more linked to oral hygiene habits than diet alone.

supporting.text: French people often drink water with meals, which helps wash away food particles and bacteria that can cause bad breath.

attacks.text: French people often drink water with meals, which helps wash away food particles and bacteria that can cause bad breath.
Drinking water alone is insufficient to prevent bad breath if oral hygiene practices like brushing and flossing are neglected.
Studies show that water consumption during meals reduces bacterial load in the mouth, even if other hygiene practices are inconsistent.
Certain foods commonly consumed in France, like garlic and cheese, are known to cause persistent bad breath regardless of water intake.
French cuisine also includes breath-freshening elements like parsley and mint, which counteract odor-causing foods.

supporting.text: Alcohol consumption, particularly wine, is common in France and can lead to dry mouth, a condition associated with bad breath.

attacks.text: Alcohol consumption, particularly wine, is common in France and can lead to dry mouth, a condition associated with bad breath.
Regular oral hygiene practices, such as brushing and flossing, are common in France and can mitigate the effects of dry mouth caused by alcohol.
Not all French people consume alcohol regularly, and even among those who do, not all experience dry mouth or bad breath.
Dry mouth is just one of many factors that can contribute to bad breath, and its impact varies widely among individuals.
Studies show that the French population has lower rates of halitosis compared to other countries, suggesting that alcohol consumption does not significantly impact overall bad breath prevalence.
